title: Part III of III: The penetrating effects of poor sleep from metabolism to genetics
content: In the final part of this 3 part series, Matthew Walker, professor of neuroscience at UC Berkeley and expert on sleep, discusses the omnipresent effects of insufficient sleep on everything from metabolism, appetite, athletic performance, decision-making, productivity, leadership, mental health, genetics, memory, and more. We also discuss the impact of caffeine and alcohol on sleep quality, the efficacy of sleep aids such as THC and CBD, and much more.

title: Effect of sleep deprivation on glucose disposal
content: Group of subjects measured by euglycemic clamps (keep glucose level steady by titrating insulin levels measure how well you dispose of glucose, primarily in muscle). Got 4 hrs of sleep a night for 2 weeks (study now replicated with 4, 5, 6 hrs for one week). 50% reduction in ability to put glucose into their muscle – (Peter says: 1 of 5 most important physiologic functions). After one week of sleep deprivation, these previously healthy people are now looking pre-diabetic (“You’re writing them a Metformin prescription.”)

title: Mechanism of how lack of sleep affects glucose regulation
content: Either, or both, can be affected. There can be a deficit in one of those two pathways (for example, in pregnancy, cells can become less sensitive so pancreas releases more insulin). With sleep deprivation, you have a deficit in BOTH. β cells become insensitive to spike in blood glucose. And the cells become insensitive to signal of insulin. Now you have an inability to clear glucose on both sides of glucose equation.

title: Insufficient sleep and impaired insulin signaling
content: Biopsied cells around umbilicus from healthy adults after 4-5 hours of sleep vs. 8 hrs of sleep. Looked at adipocyte cells taking up insulin. Amount of insulin required to phosphorylate Akt almost doubled when subjects did not get enough sleep.

title: Epigenetic changes with insufficient sleep
content: Group of healthy adults limited to 6 hours of sleep a day for 1 week (About the typical sleep adults get on avg.). They found a change in the activity of 711 genes compared to when the subjects got 8 hrs of sleep (epigenetic change in 3% of their genome, only about 20,000 genes in our genome). About half of the genes were upregulated and half downregulated. Downregulated (impaired) genes were ones associated with the immune system. The ones upregulated genes were associated with tumor production, long-term chronic inflammation, and stress / cardiovascular disease.

title: Sleep deprivation effects and reversibility
content: Sleep is not like a debt that you can repay (can’t make it up later, e.g., on weekends). The damage from lack of sleep doesn’t seem to be reversible. However, that doesn’t mean that from this point forward, it’s a waste of time to start sleeping better.

title: Sleep's impact on exercise performance, appetite, and food choices
content: When you are underslept, you are less likely to be motivated to be physically active. With enough sleep, you will make better food choices, lower your caloric intake, increase calories expended, more motivated to be active, and work out more intensely. All of these things benefit cognitive decline, so if sleep is not ultimately the thing that is transacting the cognitive benefits, maybe is it the root cause.

title: Importance of correcting sleep
content: If you have been sleep deprived in the past, don’t think that your fate is sealed. Just like people with T2D can improve by making changes to diet and exercise and how long-time smokers can improve just by quitting. Future studies will probably not be of sleep restriction but of sleep interventions and extensions.

title: Sleep and appetite regulation
content: This paper shows that subjects limited to 4-6 hours of sleep per night for 1 week will have downregulated leptin (the satiety hormone that signals to your brain that you are full and don’t need to eat anymore) is turned down and upregulated ghrelin (a hunger hormone signaling the body to eat more) is ramped up. People sleeping 6 hours a night will eat extra calories during the next day.

title: Peter's struggle with food choices when sleep deprived
content: When flying from NYC to California, he has to wake up at 4am. That is unquestionably one of the worst eating days of my life if I let it be.

title: Impact of Sleep Deprivation on Food Choices
content: When sleep deprived, people not only eat more calories but also worse foods (pizza, cookies, and ice cream instead of protein, nuts, and leafy greens). The prefrontal cortex of the brain, which keeps hedonic desires in check, is impaired by sleep deprivation. And the more primitive areas of the brain like the amygdala “erupted” in response to desirable foods.

title: Sleep Deprivation and Workplace Productivity
content: Employees who are sleeping 6 hours or less select less challenging problems, produce fewer creative solutions to the problems they do select, slack off and let others work (social loafing), and become more deviant and less ethical (they falsified data and reimbursement claims, they claimed they’d done work other people had actually done).

title: Sleep's Impact on Physical Appearance, Dating, and Mating
content: A study in Sweden found that people who were sleep deprived were consistently rated as less attractive, more sickly and tired looking. If you are trying to find a mate or be intimate, you won’t look your best if you’re sleep deprived.

title: The Impact of Sleep Deprivation on Wellness
content: There is truly no aspect of a human being’s wellness that isn’t eroded by a lack of sleep. Lack of sleep is like a broken water pipe in your home. . .it will leak down into every nook and cranny of your physiology. There are few things in your biology or your psychology that can retreat at the sign of sleep deprivation and get away unscathed.

title: Sleep and Evolution
content: In an evolutionary sense, we’ve kept this strange thing around for half a billion years. While you’re sleeping you can’t get food or mate or protect yourself or care for your children. We’ve had time to prepare for starvation (ketosis) and excess food as we evolved as a species.

title: Alcohol and Sleep
content: Alcohol is probably the most misunderstood “sleep aid”. But alcohol does 3 things to sleep: 1) it’s a sedative so works like sleeping pills… you might lose consciousness more quickly, but you’re not “falling asleep” faster. 2) alcohol fragments sleep so you wake up many more times during the night; often so brief that you don’t remember but they have an impact on your physiology. 3) alcohol blocks REM sleep, so you wake up unrefreshed and unrestored. Resting heart rate 6-8 beats higher. Heart rate variability is compressed by 20%. Respiratory rate is increased by 2 breaths/minute. Body temperature up by .3-.6 degrees.

title: Caffeine and Sleep
content: People often take caffeine (“adenosine-reducing substance”) to stay awake. Adenosine builds up like a sleepiness signal and when you have a lot, it tells you to go to sleep. Caffeine blocks adenosine receptors in the brain ⇒ it’s hitting the “mute button” on sleepiness. Even for people who say they sleep just fine after consuming caffeine, one study showed that 200 mg of caffeine before bed resulted in a 20% reduction in deep sleep (the same as aging you 20 or 30 years to get the same drop).

title: High carb meal before bed
content: A meal high in “bad” carbohydrates (i.e. bowl of cereal) can have a harmful effect on sleep quality similar to alcohol. Peter has seen this consistently in himself.

title: THC and CBD as sleep aids
content: Review of the literature on THC and CBD. THC is not a good sleep aid for a teenager (because their brain is still developing). THC does make you fall asleep faster (reduces sleep latency), but like alcohol, it blocks REM sleep. With regular use of THC, you start to lose the sleep latency benefit, and if you try to quit using it, many people get “rebound insomnia”. There’s not enough data yet on CBD as a sleep aid, although the data is more promising than THC. Falling asleep faster with CBD. Early tentative preliminary evidence suggests it does not have the same negative impact on REM. Also fewer dependency issues and don’t get insomnia rebound. CBD might also benefit some sleep disorders. Might reduce severity of sleep apnea. Might also help PTSD-related sleep problems. It’s dose dependent, and it’s not clear at this point what the optimal dose is. There may be other doses that are actually detrimental to sleep and we need to stay away from them. So it might that there is a U-curve with a “sweet spot” for dosing with other doses being detrimental to sleep. One hypothesis is that CBD may decrease your core body temperature, leading to better sleep. Another is indirect benefits through its reduction of anxiety, for which evidence is strongest right now. Anxiety is a major cause of insufficient or poor sleep. If you lower the “fight or flight” response, you get a more parasympathetic state and/or your core temperature drops. Peter has seen some anecdotal evidence of impressive results with CBD. Seems to especially work for people with existing sleep issues. For those who sleep well already, CBD doesn’t seem to improve it. And it does not work for everyone. But Peter has seen patients for which medications won’t work for them but CBD oil does, it’s not clear why.

title: Sleep and mental health: A two-way street
content: Sleep quality was suffering even though they had tried everything… Control the room temperature. Control the light. Control the nutrients and diet. Eliminate the alcohol. Eliminate the caffeine. Hour of meditation a day. 50 milligrams of Thorazine to just try to shut off the ruminative properties. But the patient was facing a difficult personal struggle. He ended up using MDMA (under clinical supervision) to deal with some of the underlying issues (trauma, anxiety, depression, etc.). The next day, and for several months now, he sleep has been fixed. Peter’s take: “I think that is an outlier situation, but sometimes these outlier situations provide an insight into a mechanism.” “To see this one thing, this one intervention work, and the patient would describe this as a transformational life experience, was just another example of the power of the mind and how the mind can get in its own way at times.” The bi-directionality of sleep and mental health.

title: The relationship between mental health and sleep
content: The rise in anxiety has walked in lockstep with a rise in insomnia. I think we’ve got enough evidence to suggest that those two are probably not coincidental, but are significantly interrelated. Mental health affects sleep, but poor sleep also affects mental health. People without psychological problems can develop depression, anxiety, poor mood, etc. One single night of sleep loss can induce clinical anxiety in a person who does not normally have it. Psychiatrists used to think poor sleep was a symptom of a disorder, but maybe they should have considered whether it was a cause. Like Peter’s patient above, curing mental problems and you can correct sleep problems.

title: The impact of sleep on memory
content: There is research showing that you can boost the size and amplitude of deep sleep brain waves with electrical stimulation. Hoping to do that for the elderly and people with dementia to see if we can retain some of their learning and memory by increasing deep sleep. You place a device on your head that measures the brain waves and then sends electrical voltage into the brain. It’s essentially trying to “sing in time” with the deep sleep waves, trying to boost the size of the slow waves (which are diminished 50 to 80% in older adults). Matthew has already been able to demonstrate in young healthy adults that it can almost double the amount of memory benefit that you get from sleep.

title: Matthew's upcoming projects
content: Brain simulation company that has just gone public. Considering writing a second book. Raising funds for the Sleep Center. There’s a “strange cluster of outliers” of people in their 70s and 80s whose sleep patterns seem resistant to the usual age-related decline in sleep so we would love to find out why. In general, Matthew wants to raise money for the center to look at some fundamental questions that are typically hard to get funding for but could make a real impact.

title: The importance of sleep in longevity
content: National Geographic coined the term, Blue Zones, as places throughout the world where people live longer. Some of the data is controversial, but questions have been asked about social factors, diet, exercise. But no one has asked about sleep in the Blue Zones, and that would be extremely difficult for me to get funding to study. Exercise, nutrition, and sleep are the three most fundamental things that keep humans alive longer and well. Yet they are spread across NIH entities instead of standing on their own.

title: Sleep’s impact on athletes: Looking at Formula One drivers
content: Sleep really matters in Formula One car racing (or any high speed car racing, really). F1 drivers are subject to incredible jet lag having to travel across the globe for races. Sleep deprivation is going to affect margin of error and reaction time, which are essential in racing. If there is one gold standard measure of insufficient sleep, it’s not only just your response time, your basic reaction time, but it’s the number of times that you miss a response. This is called a lapse, or an error of omission (You omitted a response that should have been happening). Six hours of sleep for a week can drop your reaction time by as much as 300-400 milliseconds which in F1 racing can be the difference in being first and out of the race completely. Spatial attention goes down very quickly under conditions of sleep deprivation. When other racers are on the track, it becomes strategic and you have to make multiple decisions in split seconds, and sleep affects critical components of that. It’s incredible how much your judgment can be impaired when others are on the track probably due to sleep’s impact on impatience and impulsivity (can lead to irrational thinking). It’s a physical sport too, and when your physical performance is mismatched to your natural circadian rhythm (like with jet lag) you will not be able to perform your best.

title: What separates the top professional athletes?
content: Peter says it’s the ability to be consistently exceptional. The pros must do 70+ in a row for more than 2 hours without making a single error. That is a ton of focus and concentration for a long period of time (more so than most other sports) ⇒ in neuroscience they refer to this as the “time on task effect”. The longer you do something, your sustained attention will wane for pretty much any cognitive task. The longer you apply yourself to a task, the more insufficient sleep shows. For example, for the first 30 seconds they perform as if they are rested, but at about 4-5 minutes in you really see a difference in performance if they are sleep deprived. The biggest effect of sleep deprivation in terms of time on task is in sustained attention and sustained spatial attention so paying attention to these effects would be a benefit to racers.

title: Sleep and Medicine
content: An understanding of sleep is probably the single biggest deficit within the toolkit of most physicians.

title: Nutrition Research
content: Few people are more critical of the absolute dearth of rigor in the nutrition field, but I think this is worse. It’s not the dearth in the quality of the research, it’s the dearth in the translation of that research to clinical application.

title: Sleep Advocacy
content: I am on a mission to try to reunite humanity with the sleep that it is so desperately bereft of. . .but the research has not been translated to the clinical practice. . .and that’s part of the work that I do with trying to be a sleep advocate.

title: Importance of Sleep
content: Early on in my career, I don’t think I did a very good job at communicating science, the importance of sleep to the public through the science, and that’s what I’ve been desperately trying to course correct with [Why We Sleep].
